comments.commentBody: I remember hearing about all of this ' need to share information' problem  way back after 9/11.   Apparently, that old problem is still a problem.  Incompetence  caused by administration/political party changes perhaps ? We seem to have a Republican / Democrat  Party  "  failure to communicate  ' problem  which is unfortunate for the American  taxpayers   -   who pay ALL of their salaries regardless of which party  is occupying the White House.
Can you, please, name some of those colleges which "offered the most free money"? We have 3 college bound highschooler, thus starting college selection process in earnest.

I have a son weighing his options now. First, I have to say, I don't share the opinion expressed by the majority of those posting here. I found the financial aid letters clear and unmysterious abour grants and loans.

Second, a friend of ours said an educational planner told him not to save for college at all unless he could pay for it entirely. That was bad advice. My wife and I saved regularly for college from the time our child was born. We cannot now pay the sticker price of high end private schools, but between savings, grants and paying out of current income, we will be able to afford a private school.

The "safety" schools our child applied to, where his quaiifications substantially exceeded the averages of those of the schools applied to, offered the most free money.

And don't be afraid to ask a school for more grant money. I requested more grant money from my son's first choice, attaching a copy of a more generous grant offer from a competitor, and First Choice College increased its grant offer 50%.

Republicans do not care about "jobs" as jobs are a cost. Demand creates jobs in spite of the so called "job creators" desire to hold down costs. Cutting taxes on rich people does not create demand, unless buying another Rolex or hiring a pool boy will turn the economy around. Driving down wages by off shoring and union bashing does not create demand. Perpetuating the myth that market forces can contain health care costs does not create demand. Blaming poverty on poor people does not create demand. Taking peoples eyes off the economic ball by substituting "values" issues does not create demand. We cannot continue as a nation that is expected to consume but not manufacture. The republicans will not stop until our wages at the level of Africa.

Have to take issue with your second point.  The goal for Republicans (or those who own them) is actually high unemployment, as it keeps labor costs low.  When in front of microphones, GOP politicians may flap their lips and utter sounds about "jobs", but in action they oppose any method of stimulating the economy and reducing unemployment.  See Krugman's column from April 6th-

Chris--This is unfair. Our family could afford to send our kids to college because we saved. We live in a small, older un-renovated house. We drive older cars. When we travel it's mostly to visit relatives, who are kind enough to put us up for free. Our house is not decorated. Our pets are rescues. Our hobbies are inexpensive (i.e. cross-country skiing vs. downhill). We are not fashion plates. AND our kids went to schools we and they could afford.

Not everyone who pays full freight does so out of their current paychecks, although we paid some costs that way as well. Some of us have modest-sized families and live modestly, to the benefit of our children's educations and our own retirement benefits.

David,

I attend community college classes with my daughter every day. The young ones get it. We need to worry about is whether they're discouraged by the daunting number of changes they will have to make in order to undo the harm of the last 30 years

Sorry Harry. It's hard to patent a weed that anyone can grow. That's why the folks who fight legalization have ties to Big Pharma. Many expensive feel-good drugs would become extinct.   As to costs check out Uruguay. To legalize they undercut the illegal drug market coming from Paraguay.

Well, Ms. McMahon there's an old story that explains this situation. It seems a big plant stopped working so they called in this expert. He looked and in minutes came back and hit a certain part of a pipe with a little hammer, breaking the hammer.  He presented his bill: $2505. He was asked what was the $5 for. "The hammer". What about the $2500. "Knowing where to hit." That you were not happy with a doctor telling you you were not a good candidate for bariatric surgery--a complicated procedure with lifelong side effects possible--is clear but says nothing about his expertise otherwise.

Why the disdain for ophthalmologists? We don't care for our patients any less than you do. We care a lot about good and improved outcomes, and happy people. And if you think cataract surgery is "done by a machine," I welcome you to come to the OR and hang out with us -- see for yourself. Chances are you will need cataract surgery yourself one day, and I'm sure you'll be relieved to have a good ophthalmologist. Yes we make more - but even the most basic of slit lamps will set you back a few thousand dollars. Not to mention a boatload of other equipment required in the office. It takes a ton of overhead to run an ophthalmologist's office.

You mentioned you are a psychiatrist. You may not have a lot of overhead, but you do require far more time at any visit and longitudinally than I will with any patient. You are, sadly, not properly reimbursed for this time. It's a travesty of our medical system. What you do is under appreciated and vitally important. All of us will agree. We are on the same team. There's no need to fling stones at your friends.

(But please.....never compare any of us to Rand Paul again).

The FBI was given plenty of information that should have caused them to more fully investigate Tsarnaev, and their failure to do a better job with all the information that they were given by the Russians two years earlier cannot be justified by now blaming the Russians for not having given them even more information.  After all the Russian's weren't responsible for doing the FBI's job for them.   This claim by the FBI looks like the familiar buck passing of a bureaucracy when it is exposed as having failed to do the job if was charged with doing.
Oh, no, it will be Obama as Chamberlain -- appeasement over Ukraine.
From your reply, I think you actually assumed it wasn't a joke.

Vexray,

If I may paraphrase Donald Rumsfeld from 03/30/2003:

"We know where they are [Russia's weapons of mass destruction]. They're in the area around Minsk and Moscow and east, west, south and north somewhat."
What next?   Russia might be developing WMDs?

Linda, that is the childhood I remember with great fondness. It was total freedom. We could do what we wanted, had a life of physical and mental challenges, not the least of which were the social challenges of childhood hierarchy and personal identity. There was no problem of childhood obesity with the active lives we led.

As Josh and MichLaw note, it is all marketing, spring more and more consumption of disposable stuff. It is the Disneyfication of childhood, with a much darker undertone.

Despite the gender and skin color equality, and sensitivity to culture, of men and women and gay and lesbian and trans people that is trumpeted today, why do I feel that we are more divided?

Why does a mother worry that her inquisitive 5 year old is not fitting some advertising norm?

I am distressed that any parent of a little girl who chooses flannel shirts, or a little boy who is entranced by pretty things would feel any sort of social censure, let alone overwhelming concern about their sexuality by their parent.

I have a little grand daughter. Boys clothes are much more charming, comfortable and utilitarian, but I notice that most of them have action cartoon logos, truck logos, etc., all commercial. I don't remember wearing one branded thing when I was a kid.

We are not leaving our world a better place for our little people.

Here's an interesting analysis about the pink craze for girls from NPR:

http://www.npr.org/2014/04/01/297159948/girls-are-taught-to-think-pink-b...
Ah, mate, I think you're really onto something there. Just had a light bulb pop up over my head. That makes total sense, thanks for sharing!

I don't understand where all this pink came from. I was born in a very conservative time, the early 1950s. All the little girls, including me, wore all colors of clothes (I remember corduroy trousers and cowboy boots were fashionable amongst the 5-year-old set), we played with cars and trucks, and we loved being tomboys, climbing trees and playing baseball. It seems like we all watched the old black-and-white Tarzan movies on TV on Saturdays. Then we went outside and swung around in the trees. Nobody worried that we were transgendered. We were just regular girls.
Even the girl toys we had, like toy stoves and refrigerators, looked like the ones in the kitchen. Nobody thought they had to be pink or purple.
Why was it that in a very conservative age, we little girls seemed to have more freedom when it came to clothes, toys, and playtime than girls do now?

This is a good point.  One stat we need for recently re-employed Americans is: for each, say, quintile of income for the old job, what income quintile was the new job in?  Anecdotally, there seems to be major downward movement.  If this is true, then looking only at re-employment per se as your metric of recovery misses the most important aspect of the story in terms of the larger economy.  Lowered income equals broke people, which is to say entrenching the evisceration of aggregate demand.  So, a recovery can have full, or nearly full, employment but still not move the economic needle.  Wages are only downward sticky until the day you get laid off, then you have to take whatever you can find.  And employers aren't offering much, mostly.

Precisely: student loans are not "aid". It is aid to burgeoing beyond economy's size educational-industrial complex and labeling it "aid" is just one huge, self-serving hypocrisy which not only our educational but also health care "systems" are enriching themselves at the expense of everyone else.

A loan is not "aid." It's more often than not these days, an anchor that the student ties themselves to, with the University's help – an anchor that grows over four years, and after which the University throws into the sea, degreed student attached, without further serious regard for their well-being.
Not at all, HOWARDML. Nobody doesn't love LIBRA'S OSE!

When my Librarose and I arrived @ 30 A, rather than REAR, SHE offered up a decidedly more colorful response, and "Rump" I felt, certainly filled the bill as a Bench warmer!
I wonder if the Sen. from Tenn, @2D when he first presented his case to the world for Global Warming, employed ALGORITHM calculations?
Lastly, Of course, yours truly, couldn't help but notice the relevance of tonight's Xword puz bec, my middle name appears more formally @17A, and in the lower SE corner, we almost have my better half's user name LIBRAS'OSE, and to complete the picture, we each have our own KIA Souls to tool around Quincy!
I trust my PAISANs here in WP don't feel it was somewhat rather AUSTINtatious of me to single these things out?

Howie TBOQ
My apologies for misinterpreting. Had I been paying better attention, I would have realized you were talking about the puzzle grid.

@D. Wiles:  I'd add that being able to dispose of bodily wastes(not to mention industrial wastes), without polluting our water sources, is vital to a society's continued existence. Just to make sure uor "DUH" point comes across.

"Evidence has grown that jobs are important not only to our economic well-being but also to self-esteem."

Insightful. Also, water is wet. And air is vital to lung function.

What Dave from Albuquerque writes is precisely what people claimed about women in biology and chemistry, not to mention art, several decades ago.  It's only by ignoring history that one can pretend that the underrepresentation of minorities (not just women but also African Americans and Hispanics) in certain fields is due purely to personal choice or intrinsic ability.

I get tired of the "women make choices" meme. What many people don't understand is that jobs often pay more or less precisely because they are male or female dominant. In fields that were historically male-dominated (that includes teaching, secretarial, bank clerks) as women entered the fields in greater numbers, the pay dropped. It wasn't the value of the work, but rather the perceived value of the person who did it that dictated the wages. More recently, the field of fundraising has shown the same pattern. Why should a man who pounds nails all day earn more money than a woman who pounds a keyboard?

http://www.cheesefoodnation.com

DR, you must be a lot younger than me, because when I started programming in 1980 about half my colleagues were women. The field became less appealing to women over time and over the same time period I began encountering more and more overt sexism in my workplaces. Anyone claiming that women are somehow less attracted by the work need to explain why they used to be.

I'm for the Paycheck Fairness Act and other measures aimed at ending workforce disparities between men and women. While such disparities are very difficult to stamp out, federal legislation would cause employers to more carefully police their pay practices.

Another problem: women remain notoriously underrepresented in many fields, including computer programming, commercial real estate leasing and development, and investment banking.

In America, we greatly value jobs and being employed, to the extent that we claim a person has failed morally if he/she is unemployed, even when external factors and phenomena have caused it -- such as a Great Recession or globalization.  Yet we hardly invest in job training.  Professor Holzer, from Georgetown University's Public Policy school, has written extensively about poverty and the dramatic and consistent decline of federal investments in job training over the past 30 years.  This has occurred at the same time another trend has occurred: middle-wage jobs, such as in the manufacturing sectors have greatly declined over the past 30 years while minimum wage/part-time jobs have greatly increased. Holzer cites a 70% decline of expenditures in real terms since 1979 on programs from the main federal job training programs, the Job Training Partnership Act (JTPA) and the Workforce Investment Act (WIA). We spend .01% of our GDP spent on these programs.  Why won't we do the obvious thing here and invest in our labor, our people, and the health and strength of our country?

@David Still the difference between 59% and 90% is staggering (and I didn't assert they were equal in size just that support for EU in the West is by orders of magnitude stronger than support for Custom union in the East )

Plus the fact that EU can't accept Ukraine for years to come whereas Russians' union is wide open adds to my argument that peoples' resolve to join EU is amazingly strong even in the face of big adversity and uncertainty.

No Serge, what it shows is how completely out of touch with and alien to most Ukrainians the Westerners are. Plus, most pro-EU maidan protestes actually thought that Yanukovich stopped Ukraine from joining the EU and not merely refused to sign an unequal association agreement. They are also sure that joining EU would solve all their problems overnight. So it also shows how brainwashed they are by pro-EU anti-Russian propaganda with which they are constantly bombarded by oligarch-owned Ukrainian media.

I would also like to add that, unlike Western Ukraine, the East is not so uniformly unanimous in their opinions. If in Kharkov, Donetsk and Lugansk regions you would probably find the similar 90% to 10% split in favour of the Customs Union, in the central regions (Kiev, Sumy, Poltava, Cherkasy, Zhytomir, Chernigiv) the population is much more pro-EU. That was those central regions which held the country together all that time, as people's opinion there is more reflective and representative of the Ukraine's as a whole and a clean divisions and separation there would be impossible. So until the Maidan a compromise dispensation, whereas Ukraine did not make a definitive choice between EU or Russia, was operational and the country remained united. If it was only up to the Western Ukraine and Donbass, they would have separated long time ago due to their irreconcilable differences.

So an overwhelming majority of the Western Ukraine (90%) support joining EU, while only barely over 50% in the East support getting closer to Russia.

Not exactly an even split, is it? It's not about West and East being evenly divided, but about West speaking loud and clear of wanting to join EU. And the East is wavering.

Personally, I am not against that strategy. However, the US and the Russian Federation will still have differences that makes a buffer zone necessary and that gives not just Ukraine but any of the breakaway states much more power to institute tensions that deepen this rift. Ukraine attacking Russian Federation may be a potential possibility but it must be aware of the consequences that could potentially destroy it. Is this propaganda if the charges that this could happen are true?
We would still identify with cold war possibilities if this is so and the sanctions against each would deepen.

Ukraine cuts the power to the building to pressure the dissidents.

Russia cuts the gas to the Ukraine. The pro-Russia president of Ukraine is ousted with a snap election. Crimea is annexed with a snap election.

Seems like all tactics are used by all people.

The UK is Party to the Convention on the Reduction of Statelessness which, according to my quick reading, prohibits them from stripping citizenship where doing so would render the person stateless unless that person is "seriously prejudicial to vital interests.:  So as far as I can tell the 2006 legislation to make it easier to strip citizenship from otherwise stateless persons was illegal under international law.  Not that that ever stops countries from doing whatever they want (see American torture program), but it is worth noting.

You're welcome. It probably wasn't very funny for the family of Dashawn Longfellow when the British government helped his murderer, Lee Aldhouse, secure a much more lenient sentence than he should have gotten.

Good for the Brit's. They have been around long enough to know how the game is played. 1100 years give or take a few.  We should follow their lead.  Being given the right to become an American citizen should be prized and cherished above all other allegiances and certainly not squandered by aligning oneself with the most abhorrent group of people in the world.  Any American citizen that plots to kill their fellow citizens while on foreign soil, especially,  should loose their rights to live in and be protected by this Nation.  I agree with the President on this one and the British Parliament. Send more drones.

We all loved "Pat the Bunny," one of those classic kid books that will live forever.

We're doing a seder for 30 on Monday. I've got a quart of schmaltz rendered, the brisket marinating and the sole frames for the gefilte fish stock all ready. Tomorrow I make that stock, the beef stock for braising the brisket and the chicken stock that is used instead of water for the chicken soup. Some timing has been thrown off because I have to do a window arrangement for the headquarters in San Francisco on Saturday.

My feet are already killing me.

Martin, you expect sympathy from me?  The wife is talking about the time our younger son's appendix burst (after he played 36 holes of golf), and had two surgeries to clean up the mess.  Our son only talks bout being catheterized during his stays in the hospital. I suggest you pat the brisket and suck it up.
I will long remember 'pat the brisket'.

Martin, Northwestern appealed the NRLB Regional Director's decision today about their football players being university employees who can organize a union.  I understand if NU loses, they will turn the program into FLAG football.  That's actually a good think because the NFL is already headed in that direction.
